definitions.definition: the state of being in a place or situation where there is no protection from something harmful or unpleasant

examples.text: prolonged exposure to harmful radiation
At high exposures, the chemical can affect the liver and kidneys.
the company’s exposure on the foreign exchange markets *(= to the risk of making financial losses)*
Banks will seek to minimize their exposure to risk.
The report recommends people to avoid prolonged exposure to sunlight.
human exposure to asbestos
long-term human exposure to mercury
prenatal exposure to cigarette smoke

definitions.definition: the fact of having the true facts about somebody/something told after they have been hidden because they are bad, dishonest or illegal

examples.text: his exposure as a liar and a fraud
the exposure of illegal currency deals
full exposure of the links between government officials and the arms trade
There were damaging exposures of the government's own practices.

definitions.definition: the fact of being discussed or mentioned on television, in newspapers, etc.

examples.text: Her new movie has had a lot of exposure in the media.
He receives regular exposure in the papers.
The magazine aims to give exposure to the work of women artists.
a would-be television personality who is constantly trying to get media exposure

definitions.definition: the fact of experiencing something new or different

examples.text: We try to give our children exposure to other cultures.

definitions.definition: a medical condition caused by being out in very cold weather for too long without protection

examples.text: Two climbers were brought in suffering from exposure.
Three of the men died of exposure.

definitions.definition: the length of time for which light is allowed into the camera when taking a photograph

examples.text: I used a long exposure for this one.

definitions.definition: a length of film in a camera that is used to take a photograph

examples.text: There were three exposures left on the roll of film.

definitions.definition: the act of showing something that is usually hidden

wordOrigin: early 17th cent.: from expose, on the pattern of words such as enclosure.
